title: How to Make Your Own Water Droplet Studio

steps.headline: Get the right location.
steps.description: It needs to have some type of overhang. This is to suspend the plastic bag so make sure that it can support the bag.

steps.headline: Lay down a couple sheets of paper.
steps.description: Any color will work, but remember that it needs to work with the color of the cup.

steps.headline: Put a sheet of paper behind your cup of water.
steps.description: You can fasten it to the wall or anything else that is in your droplet studio.

steps.headline: Fill the Ziploc bag about 1/3  of the way full.
Hang it directly above the cup and paper that you have positioned.
steps.description: Use tape, but make sure it's strong enough to support the bag.

steps.headline: Make any pre-adjustments that you feel need to be made.
steps.description: You want the cup and the dripping plastic bag to align.

steps.headline: Using the razor or a very sharp object, cut a very small hole in the bag so that it starts dripping.
Determine the focus.
steps.description: Do this by watching it drop and putting a pencil in that location.

steps.headline: Allow the camera to auto-focus on the pencil.
Turn your camera to manual focus.
Set the off camera flash at its lowest setting and point it at the cup of water.
Put your camera at S (Nikon) or Tv (Canon).
steps.description: Whichever one controls the speed of the shutter.

steps.headline: Start practicing.
steps.description: Don't expect to get the timing right away. It will take some time.

steps.headline: Once you have the process down, start experimenting and getting creative.

tyn: A cup with water (the cup can be any color)
Ziploc type of bag filled with water
Something sharp like a razor blade
Multiple sheets of paper (your choice of color)
